Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Spherical Porous Reactive Aggregates from Coal Bottom Ash

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Early-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project pursues research to understand the fundamental physical and chemical mechanisms for producing spherical porous reactive aggregates (SPoRA) for concrete materials using worthless coal bottom ash. Coal power plants around the country generate large volumes of bottom ash with no engineering value and a high environmental cost to the society. This project aims to convert this waste material into value-added reactive aggregates that will improve the cracking resistance of concrete by strengthening the bonding between aggregates and hardened cement. The research will estimate the savings in energy, greenhouse gas emissions, and landfilled waste when using coal bottom ash for construction materials. The project will nurture undergraduate students by incorporating co-op training into this research. Freshman and senior design projects will germinate from this project. Undergraduate students working on this project will serve as mentors for the high school students who are participating in the STEM scholar program of the institution.

Residual carbon coal bottom ash is converted to concrete aggregate materials through a sintering process by timing the initiation of volume expansion within the melt trajectory. In parallel to applying thermodynamic and kinetic modeling and experimental synthesizing of SPoRA, will be the benchmarking of its life cycle environmental impacts against conventional lightweight aggregates. The hypothesis is that partially melting the oxide compounds and subsequently combusting the residual carbon will create a porous material encapsulated by a glassy layer that exhibits pozzolanic reactivity. The highly pozzolanic reactive amorphous surface alters the microstructure of the interfacial transition zone, enhancing the cracking resistance of concrete. The dominantly crystalline core of the aggregates provides the strength. The knowledge acquired from creating lightweight aggregates by controlling the amorphous phase as a functional design requirement is transferable to other sintered lightweight aggregates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to evaluate the technical and economic feasibility and environmental sustainability of converting high residual carbon coal bottom ash to lightweight aggregates (LWA) using an innovative sintering process. Recent United States Environmental Protection Agency (U.S. EPA) regulations for the disposal of coal combustion residues (CCR) incentivize recycling efforts to convert them into value-added applications. Moreover, new rules issued by U.S. EPA on the disposal of CCR require the closure of unlined surface impoundments or retrofit with a composite liner consisting of a geomembrane and compacted clay layer, alongside leachate collection and groundwater control, all of which significantly increase disposal costs. As an alternative, this NSF project investigated opportunities to recycle CCR originating from bottom ash and off-spec fly ash, which is unsuitable as a direct addition to cement due to loss on ignition (LOI) and moisture content.

This project investigated material properties and parameters that affect the environmental and economic sustainability of recycling CCR samples obtained from two U.S. power plants into LWA for construction materials. Sphericity in LWA promotes the workability of concrete. Thus, through experiments and thermodynamic models, processing conditions for making spherical porous reactive aggregates (SPoRA) were determined by partially melting the oxide compounds and subsequently combusting the residual carbon to create a porous material encapsulated by a glassy layer. Those processing conditions sought to optimize the time to achieve a viscosity in the liquid melt phase to create a spherical shape glassy exterior layer that exhibits pozzolanic reactivity.

A sintering process was proposed that involves combining CCR with NaOH or waste glass, both of which act as fluxing agents and in the case of glass as silicate network modifiers acting to lower the temperature of forming slag. Experiments and thermodynamic models were performed to test the production of high quality SPoRA from ash samples with NaOH, whereas use of waste glass was only simulated using thermodynamic models on phase equilibria at alternative doses of glass to identify the slag formation temperature. Figure 1 provides a schematic of the process and avoided waste treatment processes and materials if recycling CCR.

Research findings showed the following:

  1. Experiments together with thermodynamic and viscosity models identified optimal additions of fluxing agent to attain desired characteristics in the final lightweight aggregate, which was were used as benchmarks against which to test waste glass as an alternative fluxing agent.
  2. Thermodynamics and empirically derived models and experimental observations on the viscosity, surface tension, heat capacity, enthalpy of fusion and thermal conductivity were used to constitutively design melt ceramics and create a custom model for the design of spherical porous reactive aggregates (SPoRA) from two different coal bottom ashes, using NaOH as an illustrative fluxing agent.
  3. To obtain the desired aggregate design, production should occur above the solidus temperature, yet viscous flow, caused by low viscosity of the CCR melt, should be limited.
  4. LWA should have a set of suitable qualities if used in lightweight concrete: appropriate specific gravity, water absorption/desorption (to absorb sufficient water before concrete mixing and desorb sufficient amount of water during self-desiccation of concrete), interconnected porous structure (to readily release the absorbed water), and in some cases round shape to increase the workability of the concrete.
  5. Nondestructive techniques were used to understand the pore structure of the SPoRA produced by sintering. Measurements found the SPoRA to possess desirable water absorption for internal curing of concrete.
  6. The spherical shape of LWA, which is influences the workability of concrete, was found to range from 1 (meaning a perfect sphere) to 0.75, suggesting that SPoRA may be a promising LWA to be used in lightweight concrete construction, lightweight geotechnical applications, internal curing of concrete and/or green roof applications.
  7. The sustainability of the production process was evaluated using LCA. Thermodynamic models enabled building life cycle assessment (LCA) models to estimate that energy and GHG emissions are minimized at operating temperatures of 1000⁰C for industrial-scale combinations with high ratios of glass to ash.
  8. Overall, this project investigated opportunities and tradeoffs for using construction infrastructure as a ?sink? for coal combustion waste.
